div.p: were expecting an invitation from the Chawyens to trade horses & therefore that the Gros Ventres would part with theirs & with less reluctance than they would have done at any other time[,] but that they had very little time left to make critical remarks & finding faults to every horse – that many of those in whom they found so many faults would not be purchased for their weight in gold[.] I told Mr Chabz if he would wait for the Borgne's arrival, that I would assure him of the best horse in the whole villg on conditions that he should be satisfied with horse & start no objections to his colour[.] Mr C. being so far satisfied I had next morning to go to every Indian who had a famous horse & use all my endeavours to make them part with one but in vain, after naming the articles they were to get in return they all sent me off with a direct refusal or a smile[.] Some of them indeed came to see the goods & wd have accepted them, had not Mr Henry adapted an opinion that their horses were inferior to the horse of those that would not sell theirs & would wish them to run thus before him but the Indians were not inclined to give him that satisfaction[.] About midday the Borgne's brother & some men of the Gros Ventres came back from the Shawyens to tell the Missurie Indians that the Borgne was wanting them all to go to the Shawyens to trade & that he would wait their arrival at the Shawyens[.] This news soon got vent thought the different Villages, & all the men and women began to make preparative to repair thither next morning[.] The Borgne's brother had thus famous horse of the Borgne's, which when that noble beast was examined by Messrs C. & H. they declared him to be without a fault excepting his colour, which was of a nut-Brown[.] Having this young man that Mr Chaboillez was the Chief who sent the Chiefs clothing to his brother two years ago & that he came in purpose to get a good horse – but that the Gros Ventres treated him with contempt & would not sell him a good horse[.]
